The chain sang its metallic hymn against the cassette, a sound more comforting to Leo Vance than any birdsong. Each rotation of the cranks was a prayer, each lungful of salt-laced air a communion. He crested the hill overlooking Avoca Beach, the early sun turning the sea into a sheet of hammered gold. Down below, the Norfolk pines stood like stoic sentinels guarding the sweep of sand. His thighs screamed a familiar, welcome protest, the lactic acid a testament to effort, to being undeniably, viscerally alive. This was his church, the winding asphalt ribbon that hugged the coastline from Terrigal to Macmasters, his penance and his reward.

The world always seemed sharper from the saddle of his carbon-fibre Ridley. Colours bled into each other with a painterly intensity, the sky a more profound blue, the scrubby bushland a deeper, more ancient green. Sometimes, though, it felt too sharp. A little unreal. Like a photograph that had been over-processed, the saturation cranked up to an impossible level. He’d blink, shake his head, and the sensation would fade, leaving only the steady thrum of the tyres on the road and the rhythmic pump of his own heart. And that other sound. A low, persistent hum, just on the edge of his hearing. He’d first noticed it a few months back, a faint electrical buzz that seemed to follow him, a single, unwavering note beneath the symphony of the world. He’d checked the wiring in his small fibro shack, unplugged the fridge, even stood in the middle of a deserted national park, but it was always there. A ghost in the machine of his own perception.

He let the bike fly down the descent, leaning into the corners with a practiced grace that belied the raw power in his legs. The wind whipped past his ears, tearing at his jersey, a furious, cleansing force that stripped away everything but the present moment. He wasn't Leo Vance, the quiet bloke who fixed watches for a living, the guy whose social life was a flat line. He was a force of nature, a blur of muscle and mechanics carving a line through the universe. For these fleeting minutes, he was untouchable.

Back at his place, the fibro creaked and settled in the growing warmth of the day. The air inside was still and cool, thick with the smell of old wood, citrus-based chain lubricant, and the faintest, most persistent trace of the sea. He leaned his bike against the wall, the frame ticking as the metal cooled. A ritual. A moment of quiet reverence for the machine. He peeled off his sweat-stiffened jersey and bib shorts, his skin slick and gleaming. As he toweled off, he glanced at the laptop sitting open on his small kitchen table. He’d left it on overnight, a bad habit. The screen glowed with the login page for his email. He barely registered it, his mind still out on the road, replaying the burn of the final climb.

It was only when he was pouring a mountain of muesli into a bowl that the subject line caught his eye. It was from a name he’d been dreaming of, hoping for, dreading.

Subject: Nation’s Spark: Grand Final Confirmation

His breath hitched. The spoon clattered from his numb fingers into the bowl, sending a spray of oats and dried fruit across the worn linoleum. He moved towards the table as if wading through water, his legs suddenly feeling weak and uncertain, a bizarre betrayal after their Herculean effort on the hills. He clicked it open.

*Dear Leo Vance,*

*Following your incredible semi-final performance, we are delighted to formally invite you to compete in the Grand Final of Nation’s Spark…*

The rest of the words swam. A roaring filled his ears, louder than the wind on the descent, louder even than the strange, ever-present hum. He gripped the back of the chair, his knuckles white. He was in. The cyclist from the sleepy Central Coast, the man whose secret talent was so esoteric, so fragile, he barely spoke of it. He was in the final. A shot at a hundred thousand dollars. A shot at a different life. A ghost of a chance, his old man would have called it, and a ghost of a smile touched Leo’s lips.

He read the email again, and then a third time, the words finally arranging themselves into concrete reality. The taping was in two weeks. Sydney. A live audience. The whole circus. A wave of nausea and adrenaline crashed through him. He laughed, a short, sharp bark of disbelief. He walked onto his small, sun-bleached verandah and stared out at the sliver of ocean visible between his neighbours’ houses. The world didn't just look saturated now; it looked incandescent. He felt so full of light and energy he thought he might actually float away.

Later, when the tremors of shock had subsided into a steady, thrumming excitement, he went to his spare room. It was the smallest room in the house, barely big enough for the single bed pushed against one wall. But the centre of the room was dominated by a long, cloth-covered table. He pulled back the sheet with the reverence of a priest unveiling a sacred object. There they sat, in a shimmering, crystalline row: twenty-four wine glasses of varying sizes and shapes. Some were delicate flutes, others robust Bordeaux glasses, a few were squat, heavy-bottomed tumblers. Each was filled with a precise amount of water, measured to the millilitre. This was his other instrument. His secret.

He dipped his fingers into a small bowl of water, moistened the tips, and touched the rim of the largest glass. A low, resonant tone filled the tiny room, a sound so pure and ethereal it seemed to come from the air itself, not from something as mundane as glass and water. He moved to the next, and the next, his fingers dancing across the rims. A melody began to form, a complex, cascading series of notes that hung in the air like chimes in a frozen garden. It was Bach. Cello Suite No. 1. A piece he usually played on his cello, but which found a new, haunting life on the glass harmonica.

The music was the total antithesis of his cycling. The bike was grit, sweat, pain, and glorious, explosive effort. The glasses were precision, stillness, and a delicate, almost heartbreaking fragility. One clumsy move, one tremor of the hand, and a note would sour or a glass would tip. It required a different kind of strength, a control so absolute it was a form of meditation. As he played, the world outside fell away. There was no bike, no talent show, no hum in his ears. There was only the vibration, the way the sound seemed to travel not through the air but through the bones in his fingers, up his arms, and into the core of his being. It was a sound like ghosts singing, and in it, he found a peace that the open road, for all its wild freedom, could never quite provide.

He was lost in the flowing river of the music when a shadow fell across the doorway. He flinched, his finger skidding on a rim and producing a painful, scraping screech.

"Sorry," Chloe said, her voice soft. "I didn't mean to scare you."

His sister stood there, holding two takeaway coffee cups. Her smile was warm, but it never quite reached her eyes. There was a permanent sadness etched into the corners of her mouth, a quiet grief that had lived with her for as long as Leo could remember. She was the only one who knew about the glasses, the one who had encouraged him to send in the audition tape in the first place.

"You're early," he said, his heart rate slowly returning to normal.

"Couldn't wait. I had a feeling." She stepped into the room, handing him a cup. Her fingers brushed his, and for a half-second, her hand felt impossibly cold, like she’d been holding a block of ice. "So?"

Leo couldn’t suppress the grin that split his face. "I'm in, Chlo. I'm in the final."

Her face lit up, a genuine, unburdened joy that was so rare for her it was like seeing the sun break through a week of rain. "Oh, Leo! I knew it! I told you!" She threw her arms around him, hugging him tightly. Her embrace felt… thin. Less solid than he expected, as if he were hugging a bundle of clothes rather than a person. He chalked it up to his own lingering adrenaline. Everything felt weird today.

"They finally saw it, Leo," she said, her voice thick with emotion as she pulled back. "What I've always seen."

They went and sat on the verandah, the sea breeze ruffling their hair. "A hundred grand, Chlo," he said, shaking his head in wonder. "I could get a proper race bike. A Pinarello Dogma, maybe. We could go to France, watch the Tour. Ride Alpe d'Huez."

She listened, nodding, but her gaze was distant, fixed on the horizon line, that impossibly sharp edge where the sky met the sea. "You deserve it," she murmured, more to the ocean than to him. "A final, perfect ride."

He thought it was a strange way to phrase it, but Chloe was often strange, her words floating in from some melancholy, faraway place only she had access to. A single tear traced a path down her cheek.

"Hey," he said gently, reaching out and wiping it away with his thumb. "These are supposed to be happy tears." His thumb came away dry. He frowned, looking at his own skin. He had definitely felt the tear, wet and warm on her face, but there was no trace of it on his. It was like he'd wiped away a mirage.

"Just so proud," she whispered, forcing another smile. "Just so proud of you, big brother."

He let it go. The whole day was strange, shimmering with a dreamlike quality he couldn't grasp. The hum was back, a low thrumming in his teeth. He took a sip of his coffee. It was rich and dark, but underneath, there was another taste he couldn't place. Faint, but constant. The taste of salt. The same salt he tasted on the road, the salt that seemed to have permanently infused his tongue. He looked out at the water, a vast, unknowable expanse of blue. He was on top of the world, his future a brilliant, sunlit path. But he couldn't shake the feeling that he was standing on something thin, something that might give way at any moment.The two of them sat in a comfortable silence for a long time, the only sounds the distant sigh of the surf and the chittering of lorikeets in a nearby gum tree. The coffee cup in Chloe’s hand seemed untouched, steam no longer rising from its surface. She held it with a delicate stillness, her knuckles pale against the cardboard. Leo felt the nervous energy of the email begin to dissipate, replaced by the familiar, low-grade anxiety of what came next. The reality of performing in front of millions of people was a far more terrifying hill to climb than anything the coast road could throw at him.

"You'll need a new piece," Chloe said, her voice cutting cleanly through his thoughts. "Something bigger than the Bach. More memorable."

"I don't know, Chlo. The Bach is my best. It's clean, it's classic." He swirled the dregs of his own coffee, watching the dark liquid coat the sides of the cup. "Maybe I just polish that. Make it flawless."

"Flawless is for auditions," she countered, turning to face him. Her eyes, usually so distant, were sharp and focused. "The final is for fireworks. You need something that will make them stop breathing. Arvo Pärt. *Spiegel im Spiegel*."

Leo almost laughed. "The Mirror in the Mirror? On wine glasses? It's a duet, for a start. It's all long, sustained notes. It's almost impossible. The resonance would die. I'd need a hundred glasses just to manage the decay."

"Then use a hundred glasses," she said, her intensity unwavering. "Don't you see, Leo? This isn't about just playing the notes. It's about showing them the impossible. It's about making something beautiful out of nothing. That's what you do. It’s who you are." She leaned forward, and for a moment, the sun behind her seemed to shine right through the edges of her hair, turning it into a translucent halo. He blinked, and the effect was gone.

He looked down at her coffee cup, still full. "You're not going to drink that?"

She followed his gaze, a flicker of confusion on her face. "Oh. Right. I'm not really thirsty." She placed the cup on the weathered timber of the verandah rail, her movements unnaturally smooth and silent. "Just think about it, Leo. *Spiegel im Spiegel*. It would be… transcendent."

The phone rang from inside, a shrill, artificial sound that shattered the morning's peace. Leo jumped, startled. It was a producer from the show, a woman named Sarah with a voice that was aggressively cheerful. The call was a whirlwind of logistics: travel arrangements, accommodation, press interviews, rehearsal schedules. Each detail was a brick being laid, building a wall of terrifying reality around him. He found himself answering in monosyllables, his mind struggling to keep up. While he listened, his eyes were fixed on Chloe, who had stood up and was now gazing out at the ocean again, her back to him. She was so still, she could have been a statue carved from driftwood.

"So we'll have a car pick you up at 0800 on Monday week. Does that work for you, Leo?" Sarah chirped.

"Yes. Fine," he mumbled, his throat dry. The hum in his ears seemed to amplify, locking onto the frequency of the phone's electronic signal.

"Great! We are all just so thrilled for you, Leo. Your talent is so… unique. We think Australia is going to fall in love with it."

He hung up, the phone feeling slick with sweat in his palm. He walked back onto the verandah, the producer's plastic enthusiasm ringing in his ears. "They're sending a car," he said, needing to say it out loud to make it real. "Press interviews." Chloe didn't turn around. Her coffee cup was gone from the rail. He glanced around the small space—it wasn't on the floor, not on the table. It had simply vanished. He felt a dizzying lurch, as if the floor had tilted beneath his feet.

"Chlo? Where did your coffee go?"

She finally turned, her expression placid. "What coffee?" she asked, her brow furrowed in genuine confusion. "You were the one with the coffee, Leo."

He stared at her, then at his own empty cup on the table, then back at her face. The lie—or the lapse, or whatever it was—was so blatant, so calmly delivered, that he felt a crack form in the bright, incandescent surface of his day. He opened his mouth to argue, to point to the spot on the rail where the cup had been just moments before, but the words died in his throat. What was the point? Arguing would only upset her, drawing that sad, fragile veil back over her face. He was probably just scrambled from the news, the lack of sleep, the hard ride. His mind was playing tricks. It had to be.

"Right," he said, forcing a smile. "Yeah. My mistake."

She smiled back, that rare, brilliant smile returning. "Now," she said, her voice light and airy again. "Go and practice. Show me how transcendent you can be."

He retreated to the spare room, the command echoing in his head. The air in the small space was thick with the silent potential of the glasses. *Spiegel im Spiegel*. The idea was absurd, a technical nightmare. But as he looked at the glistening array on the table, a defiant spark flickered within him. *It's about making something beautiful out of nothing.* He sat down, the familiar scent of water and glass filling his senses. He wouldn’t attempt the whole piece, not yet. He would just try to find the opening notes, to see if it was even possible to sustain them, to create that hypnotic, bell-like repetition the piece demanded. He moistened his fingers and touched the rim of a glass. A perfect, clear A. He let it ring, feeling the vibration travel up his arm. Then he prepared to strike the next note, the high C-sharp. As his second finger approached the rim of the smaller glass, the hum in his head sharpened, rising in pitch until it perfectly matched the A that was already hanging in the air. The two tones locked together, the external sound from the glass and the internal one in his skull, creating a disorienting, pulsating beat in the centre of his brain. The sensation was so overwhelming he pulled his hands back as if the glass were red hot. The note died, and the hum receded to its usual background murmur. He sat there, breathing heavily, his heart hammering against his ribs. It wasn't just a hum. It was a note. And it was tuned to his music.### Chapter 2

The world snapped back into focus with a painful clarity. Leo was on his stool, hands hovering over the glasses, his own ragged breathing the only sound in the small room. The hum in his skull had retreated to its familiar, unobtrusive corner on the edge of his hearing. He touched his temples, half-expecting to feel a vibration, but there was only cool, clammy skin. He tried to rationalise it. Auditory pareidolia, that's what it was. The brain's tendency to find patterns in random noise. He was stressed, sleep-deprived. His mind, wound tight as a watch spring, was simply projecting a tone onto the static that had become his constant companion. It was a logical, comforting explanation, and he clung to it like a life raft. But the feeling, the physical sensation of two sounds—one real, one imagined—locking together into a single, pulsing wave inside his own head, was too real to be dismissed so easily.

He abandoned the glasses for the rest of the day, seeking refuge in the familiar, tangible world of his craft. He sat at his workbench, a loupe screwed into his eye, and disassembled a vintage Omega Seamaster. He lost himself in the microscopic landscape of gears and jewels, the precise, mechanical logic of the movement a soothing balm on his frayed nerves. Here, cause and effect were absolute. A cleaned pallet fork meant a smoother transfer of energy; a correctly oiled balance spring meant perfect timekeeping. There were no ghosts in this machine, only elegant, predictable physics. Yet even as he worked, the memory of Chloe’s suggestion echoed in his mind. *Spiegel im Spiegel*. The Mirror in the Mirror. It was an audacious, almost arrogant choice, a piece so minimalist that any flaw, any tremor, would be laid bare. It was everything he wasn't: exposed, vulnerable, and achingly sincere. The more he tried to push the idea away, the more it took root. Flawless was for auditions. The final was for fireworks.

The next ten days became a frantic, obsessive pilgrimage. *Spiegel im Spiegel* required not just more glasses, but a broader tonal range than his current set could provide. His winding coastal rides were repurposed into scouting missions. He became a familiar, Lycra-clad figure in the op-shops and antique stores from Gosford to Wyong, tapping his fingernail gently against dusty crystal and cheap glassware, his head cocked as he listened for the potential within. He found a cavernous, long-stemmed balloon glass in a dusty corner of a Toukley second-hand shop that sang a perfect, mournful low G. A set of six mismatched crystal tumblers, discovered in a deceased estate sale in Woy Woy, provided a cluster of high, bell-like notes he hadn’t known he was missing. His fibro shack was transformed into a laboratory of sound, glasses covering every available surface, the air thick with the smell of water and the sharp tang of the isopropyl alcohol he used to clean the rims for perfect friction.

His life narrowed to two alternating states of being: the lung-burning, exhaustive fury of his morning rides, and the deep, monastic concentration of the evenings. Each night, he sat in the spare room with a digital tuner and an eyedropper, meticulously adding or subtracting water, coaxing each new glass into its precise pitch. The process was maddeningly delicate. The temperature of the room, the slightest impurity in the water, even the oils from his own skin could shift a note a fraction of a cent sharp or flat. He worked for hours, his back aching, until the array of over fifty glasses stood ready, a fragile, sprawling orchestra waiting for its conductor. He was building something impossible, and the sheer, physical effort of it all kept the stranger currents of his mind at bay.

Chloe was a constant, silent presence during this time. He never heard the front door open or the creak of a floorboard announcing her arrival. He would simply be lost in the delicate task of tuning a high B-flat, and he would glance up to find her leaning in the doorway, a faint, encouraging smile on her face. Her presence was calming, her belief in him a quiet anchor in the churning sea of his anxiety. She never offered technical advice, only a steadying affirmation that what he was doing mattered. One evening, as he struggled to sustain a long, fading note, she spoke, her voice as soft as the sound itself. "Don't force it, Leo. Just let it go. The beauty is in the way it disappears." He followed her advice, easing the pressure of his finger, and the note held for a fraction of a second longer, its decay a graceful, shimmering sigh.

Her appearances were a comfort, but they were also threaded with a quiet strangeness he couldn't ignore. One afternoon, he commented on the blue cardigan she was wearing, the same one she’d worn on their last trip to the Blue Mountains years ago. She just smiled. A moment later, he looked up from his glasses, and she was wearing a simple grey t-shirt, her arms bare. When he asked about the cardigan, she looked at him with a familiar, pitying sadness. "Leo, you're so tired. I haven't worn that old thing in ages." He felt a flush of heat rise in his cheeks, a disorienting blend of confusion and embarrassment. He was working too hard. He was seeing things. It was the only explanation that didn't make him feel like he was losing his mind.

As the days ticked down and the piece began to take shape, the hum in his head evolved. It was no longer a simple, single tone. When he played, it would shift, subtly, until it found the root note of the chord he was forming, providing a low, resonant drone that seemed to thicken the air in the room. It was unnerving, but also undeniably helpful. The external sound of the glasses and the internal thrum of the hum merged, creating a richer, more complex harmony than he could produce alone. It felt as though he had a secret accompanist, one only he could hear. The ghost in the machine was no longer just a ghost; it was a collaborator.

The night before the car was due to take him to Sydney, he was ready. The house was quiet, the moon a silver disc in the black sky. Chloe stood in the doorway, a pale silhouette against the dim light of the hallway. "Play it for me," she whispered. "The whole thing. Just once." He took a deep, steadying breath, dipped his fingers in the water, and began. The opening piano arpeggio, translated to the crystalline voices of the glasses, filled the room. Then his right hand began the simple, haunting violin melody. The notes hung in the air, each one a perfect, shimmering pearl. The music was slow, meditative, a conversation between two voices—one searching, one echoing. The hum in his head settled on a low, perfect C, a foundational tone that gave the ethereal music an unexpected gravity. He was no longer just playing notes; he was weaving a spell. The pain in his legs from the morning’s ride, the anxiety about the final, the strange glitches in his perception—it all dissolved into the pure, transcendent sound. It was more beautiful than he had ever imagined it could be.

When the final note faded into absolute silence, he kept his hands poised over the glasses for a long moment, the feeling of the vibrations still tingling in his fingertips. A profound sense of peace washed over him. He had done it. He had taken her impossible suggestion and made it real. He felt a tear of pure, unadulterated relief trace a path down his own cheek. "Chlo," he said, his voice thick with emotion, turning his head towards the door. "What do you think?" But the doorway was empty. The hallway behind it was dark. A faint, salty breeze drifted through the house from the open verandah door, stirring the sheet he had used to cover the glasses. "Chloe?" he called out, his voice louder this time, a note of panic creeping in. He stood up, his legs unsteady, and walked into the living room. The house was still, empty. He grabbed his phone from the kitchen table and dialled her number, a number he now realised with a sudden, chilling clarity that he hadn't dialled in months. He had texted, but she rarely replied. She always just… showed up. The phone didn't even ring. A recorded voice, cold and robotic, spoke in his ear. *"The number you have called has been disconnected."*The robotic voice repeated its cold, synthesized message, and Leo hung up, his thumb pressing the 'end call' icon with a tremor he couldn't control. A mistake. He must have dialled the wrong number, a slip of the finger. His contacts list was a mess. He scrolled through it, his heart thumping a panicked, irregular rhythm against his ribs. There she was. ‘Chloe’. He stared at the name, then at the number beneath it, confirming it digit by digit before pressing the call button again. He held the phone so tight his knuckles ached, listening past the manufactured ringing tone for the familiar, slightly weary warmth of his sister's hello. The ringing cut out. *“The number you have called has been disconnected.”*

A wave of vertigo washed over him, so intense he had to grip the kitchen counter to stay upright. Disconnected. The word was an absurdity, a piece of a puzzle that belonged to an entirely different box. People didn't just disconnect their numbers without telling anyone. He fumbled back to his message history, scrolling frantically. There were his texts, a long, one-sided stream of consciousness sent over months. Updates on his training, complaints about the tourists, a photo of a particularly beautiful sunrise over the water. And her replies… he searched for them, his eyes scanning the screen, but there were none. He could *remember* her responses, remember her joking about his Lycra obsession, her encouragement, her telling him she was proud. He could hear her voice in his head as clearly as he could hear the hum, but there was no digital trace. It was a conversation with a phantom.

The past ten days snapped into a new, terrifying focus. A collage of impossible moments he had wilfully ignored. Her hand, impossibly cold. The hug that felt like embracing air. The disappearing coffee cup, the tear he’d wiped that left his thumb dry. The blue cardigan that had flickered out of existence and become a t-shirt. He had chalked it all up to his own exhaustion, to the pressure, to the strange, saturated quality the world had taken on. But they weren't glitches in his perception; they were clues. Warnings. Her words came back to him, no longer poetic but imbued with a chilling, literal gravity. *The beauty is in the way it disappears.* She hadn't been talking about the music. He staggered out onto the verandah, the place where she had been sitting not an hour before. He ran his hand over the weathered timber rail where her non-existent coffee cup had rested. There was nothing. No trace of her, not even the faintest indentation in the fabric of reality. She had been a mirage woven from sea-salt and memory.

He stumbled back inside, a frantic energy seizing him. He needed proof. Not of her absence, which was suddenly a suffocating certainty, but of her last known point of existence. When had he last truly *seen* her? Not the calm, sad-eyed spectre who floated in and out of his house, but his sister. The real Chloe. The one who laughed too loud, who left scuff marks on the floor, who drank her coffee black and scalding hot. He tore open a drawer full of junk, his hands shaking as he rummaged past old receipts and spare watch batteries until he found a small stack of faded photographs held together by a brittle rubber band. He snapped it, the photos scattering across the linoleum like fallen leaves. Him and Chloe as kids, gap-toothed on a swing set. Chloe at her university graduation, her smile wide and real. And then the last one. The two of them, standing on the Skillion at Terrigal, the wind whipping their hair. She was wearing the blue cardigan. The photo was dated, the timestamp in the corner a small, brutal fact: 18 months ago. There was nothing more recent.

His mind, no longer able to deny the truth, offered up the memory it had so violently suppressed. Not a dream this time, but a jagged shard of reality. A rain-swept stretch of the Pacific Highway, late at night. The blinding glare of headlights swerving across the median strip. He wasn't there, but he remembered the phone call, the one that came from a policeman, not from Chloe. He remembered the drive to the hospital, the clinical smell, the hushed, sympathetic voices. He remembered the world turning to grey static, the same static that hummed in his ears to this day. He had built an entire world, a whole relationship, in the eighteen months since, a fragile fantasy of a sister who was still there to guide him, to believe in him. The hum in his head wasn't a ghost in the machine of his perception; it was the machine itself, broken. It was the sound of his own grief, a single, unwavering note he had refused to hear.

He found himself back in the spare room, standing before the fragile orchestra he had built at her command. Fifty-seven glasses, each one filled with a precise measure of water and hope, now looked like a crystalline tomb. *Spiegel im Spiegel*. The Mirror in the Mirror. He had thought he was creating a duet. But he was the only musician. He had been playing for an audience of one, a ghost of his own making, a reflection in the mirror of his own shattered mind. He looked at the largest glass, the one that sang the mournful low G. In its curved surface, his own reflection stared back, distorted and monstrous, the face of a man who hadn't even known he was alone. The silence in the house was no longer peaceful. It was absolute. In eight hours, a car would arrive to take him to Sydney, to the grand final, to the culmination of a dream that was no longer his own. He had a choice. He could shatter the glasses, and with them, the beautiful, terrible lie he had built. Or he could play. He could go and play her song, a final, perfect ride into the heart of his own madness.### Chapter 3

He did not shatter the glasses. The thought came and went, a brief, violent impulse that was immediately smothered by the profound inertia that had taken hold of him. Smashing them would have been an action, a sound, a release. But the truth demanded none of that. It demanded only silence. He stood in the doorway of the small room for a time he couldn't measure, simply looking at the shimmering array. The moonlight catching the rims made them look like a constellation of tiny, frozen mouths, all arrested mid-song. He was not a man who had been lied to; he was a man who had composed an entire symphony of lies for himself. The effort of it, the sheer, unconscious will it must have taken to construct and maintain the phantom of his sister for eighteen months, was more exhausting than any climb, any race. He felt a weariness so deep it seemed to settle in his bones, turning them to lead.

He didn't sleep. He sat on the edge of his bed, the photo of him and Chloe at Terrigal in his hand, the flimsy card a tangible anchor to a time before the static. He traced the outline of her face, her real, laughing face, not the sad, translucent mask his mind had conjured. He finally allowed himself to remember the details his brain had so carefully buried: the frantic, sobbing phone call to his parents; the smell of antiseptic and cheap coffee in the hospital waiting room; the doctor’s gentle, useless words. The hum in his ears, which he now understood as the tinnitus of the soul, swelled to fill the silence, a constant, unwavering drone that was the true sound of his life. The world outside his window slowly transitioned from the deep indigo of night to the bruised purple of dawn, but the light brought no warmth, no colour. The world no longer looked saturated; it looked washed out, a photograph left too long in the sun.

When the sleek, black hire car pulled up outside, its engine a low, expensive purr, Leo moved like an automaton. He packed a bag with a few t-shirts and his cycling kit—a reflex, nothing more. Then came the real task. He began to pack the glasses. With a preternatural slowness, he wrapped each one in layers of bubble wrap and old towels, his movements infinitely gentle. He was no longer a musician packing his instrument; he was an archaeologist handling priceless, impossibly fragile artefacts from a lost civilization. Each glass was a memory of her, of the ghost-her he had invented. The robust Bordeaux glass that he’d tuned to her impossible instruction. The delicate flute whose high note she had praised. Packing them felt like a betrayal, and also like the only sane thing to do. He was taking his grief with him, boxing it up to be put on display. The driver, a young man with an aggressively fashionable haircut, helped him load the carefully marked boxes into the boot, offering a stream of cheerful chatter about traffic and the weather that Leo didn't even try to process.

The drive to Sydney was a journey through a landscape of ghosts. As the car sped down the M1, every roadside memorial of plastic flowers, every glimpse of rain-slicked asphalt, sent a jolt of cold dread through him. The driver’s attempts at conversation bounced off the thick wall of Leo’s silence. "Big night, the final, eh? Must be pumped," the driver said, glancing at him in the rearview mirror. He started with a simple C-major scale, the notes rough and not perfectly in tune, but solid and real. His muscle memory, buried for over a decade, slowly began to stir. He found a fragment of a simple folk song they had both learned as children, the melody emerging hesitantly at first, then with a growing confidence. The cello's voice was forgiving, its resonance covering his small mistakes, its warmth encouraging him. Anna had put her book down and was watching him, not with pity or concern, but with a quiet, luminous curiosity, as if she were meeting a part of him for the very first time.

He played for nearly an hour, the simple tunes of his childhood flowing one into another. The music was not a performance or a eulogy; it was a conversation with his own past, a re-acquaintance with a part of himself he had thought long lost. The act of making music with this instrument, the one that had been hers, was not painful. It was a connection, a continuation. He was not summoning her ghost; he was simply picking up a conversation that had been interrupted. He finished on a low, sustained C, letting the note resonate, feeling the deep vibration travel from the body of the cello through his own chest, a steadying, grounding hum. He lowered the bow, and the last of the note’s warmth faded into the sound of the rain outside. He looked at Anna, and in her soft smile, he saw not the end of a painful story, but the beautiful, unexpected beginning of a new harmony, a life filled with every kind of music.### Chapter 10

The cello did not replace the other instruments in his life; it simply took its place alongside them. The rhythmic hymn of his bicycle chain remained his morning prayer, the delicate ticking of a watch escapement his afternoon meditation. The cello became his evening vespers. The first few weeks were a study in physical re-acquaintance, a discipline of the body. The pads of his left-hand fingers, softened by years of light contact with glass rims, had to be retrained. He worked through simple scales and exercises, pressing down on the strings, re-forming the calluses, feeling the familiar, satisfying ache in the muscles of his hand and shoulder. It was the work of reclaiming a physical language, a stark contrast to the ethereal, almost disembodied touch required for the glasses. The sound he made was grounded, full of the friction of horsehair on steel, the resonance of timber, the undeniable presence of a physical object vibrating against his own body.

Anna treated the cello’s re-emergence not as a fragile archaeological find to be handled with hushed reverence, but as a simple, welcome addition to their home. It stood in the corner of their living room, its reddish-brown curves catching the afternoon light, as much a part of the furniture as the worn armchair or the stack of her books on the floor. She would sit reading on the sofa while he practiced, the slow, sometimes scratchy sound of his scales providing a domestic soundtrack to their evenings. She never offered praise or critique, only a quiet, constant presence that stripped the act of all self-consciousness. Her acceptance was so complete that it allowed the cello to become what it was: not a monument to his sister, but simply an instrument, a source of music waiting to be played.

One evening, after weeks of patient practice had restored a measure of strength and dexterity to his hands, he knew he was ready to revisit the piece that had defined an era of his life. He found the old book of Bach's Cello Suites, its pages yellowed and soft as cloth, the faint scent of rosin and time clinging to them. He opened it to the Prelude of Suite No. 1, the familiar cascade of notes looking like a transcription of a dream. He could still feel the phantom sensation of playing it on the glasses, the cold, fragile rims, the haunting, disembodied sound. He took a deep, steadying breath, raised the bow, and began.

The music that filled the room was the same, yet entirely different. Where the glasses had produced a sound like ghosts singing, fragile and heartbreakingly pure, the cello gave the music a body. The notes were warm, rich, and grounded, each one connected to the next by the physical pull of the bow and the muscular intention of his fingers. The arpeggios were not a crystalline cascade, but a flowing river of sound, with eddies and currents and a deep, resonant undertow. It was no longer a lament for an absence. It was a celebration of a memory, imbued with all the complexity, strength, and resilience of a life fully lived. The sorrow was still there, woven into the music's DNA, but it was now part of a larger tapestry of love, nostalgia, and profound gratitude. It was the sound of a human voice, full of breath and muscle, telling a story of loss, but also of enduring connection.

As the final, low G resonated through the room, a new idea began to form in Leo’s mind, a spark of quiet, creative curiosity. He didn't put the cello away. Instead, he stood up and went to the study, returning with three of his most resonant wine glasses and a small bowl of water. He set them on the coffee table beside him. Anna looked up from her book, her expression intrigued. "What are you doing?" she asked softly. "I'm not sure," Leo confessed, a small, experimental smile on his face. "I just want to see if they can talk to each other."

He began with the cello, drawing a long, low, foundational C from its deepest string, a note that felt like the steady floor of the earth. He held the drone, letting the room fill with its warmth. Then, with his right hand, he reached over, dipped a finger in the water, and traced the rim of the largest glass. A high, clear, impossibly pure E emerged, hanging in the air above the cello's earthy drone like a single, distant star. The effect was breathtaking. The two sounds, one born of wood and gut, the other of glass and water, did not compete. They complemented each other perfectly, the cello’s warmth giving the glass’s ethereal note a place to land, the glass’s clarity illuminating the cello’s rich complexity.

He began to improvise, a simple call-and-response. The cello would state a deep, melodic phrase, and the glasses would answer with a delicate, bell-like echo. It was a conversation between the body and the spirit, between the tangible memory and its lingering, transcendent essence. The woody voice spoke of shared childhoods, of laughter in a sunlit backyard, of a physical, living person. The crystalline voice spoke of the quiet ache of absence, of the shape a person leaves in the world after they are gone, of the beautiful sorrow he had finally learned to hold without being broken by it. The music was a complete, honest portrait of his love and his grief, finally holding hands.

He found a simple, repeating chord progression on the cello, and over it, his other hand began to trace a slow, beautiful melody on the glasses. It was a new composition, born not of pain or obsession, but of integration. The two disparate parts of his musical life, and of his own heart, were finally playing in harmony. The sound filled their small, warm living room, a music that was at once sad and joyful, earthy and ethereal, a perfect expression of the beautiful, complex, and ongoing conversation between life and loss. Anna sat listening, silent tears tracing paths down her cheeks, tears not of sadness, but of a profound and beautiful understanding. In the centre of that rich, layered harmony, Leo listened for the hum, the old static of his soul. It wasn't there. It hadn't been silenced or conquered. It had simply found its proper place, a single, quiet note absorbed into the great, compassionate chord of his own life. The music was whole, and so was he.The deep, resonant silence that followed the music was more profound than any note he had played. It was a silence filled not with absence, but with a new, settled presence. Leo lowered the cello’s bow, his arm feeling heavy, his body humming with the ghost of the vibrations. He looked at Anna, whose quiet tears glistened in the soft lamplight. Her expression was not one of pity, but of someone who had just witnessed a difficult, beautiful truth being told. She reached out, not to comfort him, but simply to rest her hand on his arm, a gesture of shared understanding that went deeper than words. He had spent years trying to articulate his grief, first through silence, then through the ethereal lament of the glasses. Now, in the interwoven voices of the two instruments, he had finally spoken a complete sentence, one that acknowledged both the wound and the healing, the echo and its source.

He found he had no desire to return to the complex, atmospheric compositions he had been creating in solitude. That music had been the sound of searching, of a man trying to map the geography of his own sorrow. The duet between the cello and the glasses was the sound of having arrived. It became a quiet, occasional practice, something he turned to not out of a need to express pain, but out of a simple desire to hear the two halves of his story speak to one another. He would play on quiet Sunday mornings, the rich voice of the cello and the clear ring of the glass blending with the scent of brewing coffee and the salty air drifting in from the ocean. It was no longer a performance or a practice; it was a form of journaling, a private language he now shared with Anna, a quiet affirmation that the most disparate parts of a life could, with patience and love, be brought into harmony.

As winter gave way to the first tentative warmth of spring, the Chloe Vance Spark Foundation prepared for its annual remembrance ceremony, a small, informal gathering at sunrise on the headland for the families of surf club members who had been lost over the years. Anna, in her role as coordinator, approached him one evening as they sat on the verandah. She was hesitant, her usual directness softened by the sensitivity of the request. The committee, she explained, had wondered if he might consider playing. Not a performance, she stressed, but just a quiet piece of music to accompany the dawn, something to hold the space for the shared, unspoken grief of the community. Leo felt the old, familiar instinct to retreat, to keep his music and his sorrow private. But the instinct was weaker now, a ghost of an old reflex. This was not a television studio demanding a spectacle; it was his community, their community, asking him to share a language they knew he spoke fluently.

On the morning of the ceremony, he stood on the grassy headland overlooking the sea. The sky to the east was a wash of soft pink and bruised purple. A small gathering of around thirty people stood in a quiet semicircle, their faces illuminated by the gentle, growing light. His parents were there, standing shoulder to shoulder, and Anna was beside him, her presence a calm and steady anchor. He did not bring his full orchestra. He brought only the cello and a single, perfect wine glass. As the first sliver of the sun breached the horizon, he began to play. He started with a low, simple drone on the cello, a sound like the turning of the earth itself. Then, he touched the rim of the glass, and a single, pure note floated out into the cool morning air, hanging there like the morning star. He played no specific piece, but wove a slow, meditative improvisation between the two voices. The cello spoke of memory, of love, of the solid, earthy weight of a life. The glass spoke of absence, of spirit, of the light that remains. The music was a shared prayer, a quiet acknowledgement of both the ocean’s beauty and its unforgiving power, of the love that persists and the sorrow that softens with time. He was not the star; he was simply a conduit, his music a vessel for the quiet, collective heart of his community. When the sun had fully risen, casting a brilliant, golden path across the water, he let the final note fade into the sounds of the morning—the waves, the gulls, and the quiet, shared breathing of the people around him. He lowered his bow, his heart not empty, but full.As the sun climbed higher, warming the cool morning air, the small crowd began to disperse. There was no applause, no rush to congratulate him as there had been in that other life. Instead, people came up to him one by one, their faces open and unguarded. An elderly man, whose wife had been a keen surfer in the sixties, simply laid a hand on Leo’s shoulder and gave a single, firm nod, his eyes wet. Mrs. Gable, from two streets over, touched his arm and whispered, “That was for all of them, dear. Thank you.” His parents were the last to approach. His mother hugged him, a solid, grounding embrace that was the complete opposite of the phantom hug his memory had once conjured, and he held her tightly back. His father, a man of few words, simply looked from the cello to Leo’s face, his own expression a mixture of weathered grief and profound pride. “That was her song, son,” he said, his voice thick. “You found it.”

They walked back to the shack as the town began to stir, the scent of coffee and baking bread drifting from the small strip of cafes. Leo carried the cello case in one hand, its weight a familiar, reassuring burden. Anna walked beside him, her shoulder occasionally brushing his, their steps falling into an easy, synchronized rhythm. She didn’t fill the silence with questions about how he felt or platitudes about the service. Instead, she looked out at the brightening sea and said, “Looks like the swell is dropping. Should be good for the Nippers tomorrow.” Her simple, forward-looking statement was the most sensitive thing she could have said. It placed him firmly in the present, in the ongoing stream of life with its responsibilities and small pleasures. He looked at her, at the way the early sun caught the stray hairs at her temple, and felt a surge of gratitude so immense it was almost dizzying. He had spent so long walking alone, his own footsteps the only sound against the internal hum. Now, there was this other rhythm, steady and real, beside him on the path.

The house, when they returned, was filled with light. The sun streamed through the clean windows, illuminating the dust motes dancing in the air and warming the honey-coloured floorboards. The space no longer felt like a quiet refuge from the world, but a part of it, open and breathing. While Anna started making a pot of coffee, Leo carefully wiped the rosin from the cello’s strings with a soft cloth, the small, domestic ritual an act of quiet care rather than obsessive maintenance. The instrument rested against its stand in the corner, a piece of his family’s history that was now, finally, at peace. He looked around the room, at the pile of Anna’s books on the table, at the bright crayon-drawing from the Nippers stuck to the fridge, at the schematics for a complex watch movement laid out on his workbench. All the disparate parts of his life were here, coexisting in the warm, quiet light, and the sight filled him with a sense of profound, settled rightness.

A few days later, he took the Ridley out for a ride. It was a perfect autumn morning, the air crisp and clean, the sky a deep, cloudless blue. The chain sang its metallic hymn against the cassette, but it was just a sound now, the pleasant, mechanical music of a well-oiled machine, not a prayer against the silence. His thighs screamed their familiar protest on the climb up to the headland, the lactic acid a testament not to penance, but to the simple, visceral joy of effort, of being undeniably, viscerally alive. At the crest of the hill, he stopped, clipping out and leaning his bike against the guardrail, the same spot where his story had begun. He looked out at the familiar vista: the sweep of sand, the stoic Norfolk pines, the sea a brilliant, hammered silver under the morning sun. The world was sharp and clear, its colours true. He closed his eyes and listened, not for anything in particular, but to everything at once. He heard the distant surf, the call of a currawong, the gentle ticking of his bike frame as the metal cooled. And somewhere, in the vast, quiet space behind it all, he was aware of the memory of a hum, the faint, high-frequency ghost of a sound that had once been the centre of his universe. It was gone. Not silenced, not conquered, but integrated, faded into the rich, layered texture of a life that was finally being lived. He opened his eyes, took a deep lungful of the salt-laced air, and smiled. He clipped back in and pushed off, letting the bike fly down the descent, a quiet man on a bicycle, riding not to escape his past, but to meet his future, carving a steady, joyful line down the sunlit road toward home.

The chain sang its metallic hymn against the cassette, a sound more comforting to Leo Vance than any birdsong. Each rotation of the cranks was a prayer, each lungful of salt-laced air a communion. He crested the hill overlooking Avoca Beach, the early sun turning the sea into a sheet of hammered gold. Down below, the Norfolk pines stood like stoic sentinels guarding the sweep of sand. His thighs screamed a familiar, welcome protest, the lactic acid a testament to effort, to being undeniably, viscerally alive. This was his church, the winding asphalt ribbon that hugged the coastline from Terrigal to Macmasters, his penance and his reward.

The world always seemed sharper from the saddle of his carbon-fibre Ridley. Colours bled into each other with a painterly intensity, the sky a more profound blue, the scrubby bushland a deeper, more ancient green. Sometimes, though, it felt too sharp. A little unreal. Like a photograph that had been over-processed, the saturation cranked up to an impossible level. He’d blink, shake his head, and the sensation would fade, leaving only the steady thrum of the tyres on the road and the rhythmic pump of his own heart. And that other sound. A low, persistent hum, just on the edge of his hearing. He’d first noticed it a few months back, a faint electrical buzz that seemed to follow him, a single, unwavering note beneath the symphony of the world. He’d checked the wiring in his small fibro shack, unplugged the fridge, even stood in the middle of a deserted national park, but it was always there. A ghost in the machine of his own perception.

He let the bike fly down the descent, leaning into the corners with a practiced grace that belied the raw power in his legs. The wind whipped past his ears, tearing at his jersey, a furious, cleansing force that stripped away everything but the present moment. He wasn't Leo Vance, the quiet bloke who fixed watches for a living, the guy whose social life was a flat line. He was a force of nature, a blur of muscle and mechanics carving a line through the universe. For these fleeting minutes, he was untouchable.

Back at his place, the fibro creaked and settled in the growing warmth of the day. The air inside was still and cool, thick with the smell of old wood, citrus-based chain lubricant, and the faintest, most persistent trace of the sea. He leaned his bike against the wall, the frame ticking as the metal cooled. A ritual. A moment of quiet reverence for the machine. He peeled off his sweat-stiffened jersey and bib shorts, his skin slick and gleaming. As he toweled off, he glanced at the laptop sitting open on his small kitchen table. He’d left it on overnight, a bad habit. The screen glowed with the login page for his email. He barely registered it, his mind still out on the road, replaying the burn of the final climb.

It was only when he was pouring a mountain of muesli into a bowl that the subject line caught his eye. It was from a name he’d been dreaming of, hoping for, dreading.

Subject: Nation’s Spark: Grand Final Confirmation

His breath hitched. The spoon clattered from his numb fingers into the bowl, sending a spray of oats and dried fruit across the worn linoleum. He moved towards the table as if wading through water, his legs suddenly feeling weak and uncertain, a bizarre betrayal after their Herculean effort on the hills. He clicked it open.

*Dear Leo Vance,*

*Following your incredible semi-final performance, we are delighted to formally invite you to compete in the Grand Final of Nation’s Spark…*

The rest of the words swam. A roaring filled his ears, louder than the wind on the descent, louder even than the strange, ever-present hum. He gripped the back of the chair, his knuckles white. He was in. The cyclist from the sleepy Central Coast, the man whose secret talent was so esoteric, so fragile, he barely spoke of it. He was in the final. A shot at a hundred thousand dollars. A shot at a different life. A ghost of a chance, his old man would have called it, and a ghost of a smile touched Leo’s lips.

He read the email again, and then a third time, the words finally arranging themselves into concrete reality. The taping was in two weeks. Sydney. A live audience. The whole circus. A wave of nausea and adrenaline crashed through him. He laughed, a short, sharp bark of disbelief. He walked onto his small, sun-bleached verandah and stared out at the sliver of ocean visible between his neighbours’ houses. The world didn't just look saturated now; it looked incandescent. He felt so full of light and energy he thought he might actually float away.

Later, when the tremors of shock had subsided into a steady, thrumming excitement, he went to his spare room. It was the smallest room in the house, barely big enough for the single bed pushed against one wall. But the centre of the room was dominated by a long, cloth-covered table. He pulled back the sheet with the reverence of a priest unveiling a sacred object. There they sat, in a shimmering, crystalline row: twenty-four wine glasses of varying sizes and shapes. Some were delicate flutes, others robust Bordeaux glasses, a few were squat, heavy-bottomed tumblers. Each was filled with a precise amount of water, measured to the millilitre. This was his other instrument. His secret.

He dipped his fingers into a small bowl of water, moistened the tips, and touched the rim of the largest glass. A low, resonant tone filled the tiny room, a sound so pure and ethereal it seemed to come from the air itself, not from something as mundane as glass and water. He moved to the next, and the next, his fingers dancing across the rims. A melody began to form, a complex, cascading series of notes that hung in the air like chimes in a frozen garden. It was Bach. Cello Suite No. 1. A piece he usually played on his cello, but which found a new, haunting life on the glass harmonica.

The music was the total antithesis of his cycling. The bike was grit, sweat, pain, and glorious, explosive effort. The glasses were precision, stillness, and a delicate, almost heartbreaking fragility. One clumsy move, one tremor of the hand, and a note would sour or a glass would tip. It required a different kind of strength, a control so absolute it was a form of meditation. As he played, the world outside fell away. There was no bike, no talent show, no hum in his ears. There was only the vibration, the way the sound seemed to travel not through the air but through the bones in his fingers, up his arms, and into the core of his being. It was a sound like ghosts singing, and in it, he found a peace that the open road, for all its wild freedom, could never quite provide.

He was lost in the flowing river of the music when a shadow fell across the doorway. He flinched, his finger skidding on a rim and producing a painful, scraping screech.

"Sorry," Chloe said, her voice soft. "I didn't mean to scare you."

His sister stood there, holding two takeaway coffee cups. Her smile was warm, but it never quite reached her eyes. There was a permanent sadness etched into the corners of her mouth, a quiet grief that had lived with her for as long as Leo could remember. She was the only one who knew about the glasses, the one who had encouraged him to send in the audition tape in the first place.

"You're early," he said, his heart rate slowly returning to normal.

"Couldn't wait. I had a feeling." She stepped into the room, handing him a cup. Her fingers brushed his, and for a half-second, her hand felt impossibly cold, like she’d been holding a block of ice. "So?"

Leo couldn’t suppress the grin that split his face. "I'm in, Chlo. I'm in the final."

Her face lit up, a genuine, unburdened joy that was so rare for her it was like seeing the sun break through a week of rain. "Oh, Leo! I knew it! I told you!" She threw her arms around him, hugging him tightly. Her embrace felt… thin. Less solid than he expected, as if he were hugging a bundle of clothes rather than a person. He chalked it up to his own lingering adrenaline. Everything felt weird today.

"They finally saw it, Leo," she said, her voice thick with emotion as she pulled back. "What I've always seen."

They went and sat on the verandah, the sea breeze ruffling their hair. "A hundred grand, Chlo," he said, shaking his head in wonder. "I could get a proper race bike. A Pinarello Dogma, maybe. We could go to France, watch the Tour. Ride Alpe d'Huez."

She listened, nodding, but her gaze was distant, fixed on the horizon line, that impossibly sharp edge where the sky met the sea. "You deserve it," she murmured, more to the ocean than to him. "A final, perfect ride."

He thought it was a strange way to phrase it, but Chloe was often strange, her words floating in from some melancholy, faraway place only she had access to. A single tear traced a path down her cheek.

"Hey," he said gently, reaching out and wiping it away with his thumb. "These are supposed to be happy tears." His thumb came away dry. He frowned, looking at his own skin. He had definitely felt the tear, wet and warm on her face, but there was no trace of it on his. It was like he'd wiped away a mirage.

"Just so proud," she whispered, forcing another smile. "Just so proud of you, big brother."

He let it go. The whole day was strange, shimmering with a dreamlike quality he couldn't grasp. The hum was back, a low thrumming in his teeth. He took a sip of his coffee. It was rich and dark, but underneath, there was another taste he couldn't place. Faint, but constant. The taste of salt. The same salt he tasted on the road, the salt that seemed to have permanently infused his tongue. He looked out at the water, a vast, unknowable expanse of blue. He was on top of the world, his future a brilliant, sunlit path. But he couldn't shake the feeling that he was standing on something thin, something that might give way at any moment.

The two of them sat in a comfortable silence for a long time, the only sounds the distant sigh of the surf and the chittering of lorikeets in a nearby gum tree. The coffee cup in Chloe’s hand seemed untouched, steam no longer rising from its surface. She held it with a delicate stillness, her knuckles pale against the cardboard. Leo felt the nervous energy of the email begin to dissipate, replaced by the familiar, low-grade anxiety of what came next. The reality of performing in front of millions of people was a far more terrifying hill to climb than anything the coast road could throw at him.

"You'll need a new piece," Chloe said, her voice cutting cleanly through his thoughts. "Something bigger than the Bach. More memorable."

"I don't know, Chlo. The Bach is my best. It's clean, it's classic." He swirled the dregs of his own coffee, watching the dark liquid coat the sides of the cup. "Maybe I just polish that. Make it flawless."

"Flawless is for auditions," she countered, turning to face him. Her eyes, usually so distant, were sharp and focused. "The final is for fireworks. You need something that will make them stop breathing. Arvo Pärt. *Spiegel im Spiegel*."

Leo almost laughed. "The Mirror in the Mirror? On wine glasses? It's a duet, for a start. It's all long, sustained notes. It's almost impossible. The resonance would die. I'd need a hundred glasses just to manage the decay."

"Then use a hundred glasses," she said, her intensity unwavering. "Don't you see, Leo? This isn't about just playing the notes. It's about showing them the impossible. It's about making something beautiful out of nothing. That's what you do. It’s who you are." She leaned forward, and for a moment, the sun behind her seemed to shine right through the edges of her hair, turning it into a translucent halo. He blinked, and the effect was gone.

He looked down at her coffee cup, still full. "You're not going to drink that?"

She followed his gaze, a flicker of confusion on her face. "Oh. Right. I'm not really thirsty." She placed the cup on the weathered timber of the verandah rail, her movements unnaturally smooth and silent. "Just think about it, Leo. *Spiegel im Spiegel*. It would be… transcendent."

The phone rang from inside, a shrill, artificial sound that shattered the morning's peace. Leo jumped, startled. It was a producer from the show, a woman named Sarah with a voice that was aggressively cheerful. The call was a whirlwind of logistics: travel arrangements, accommodation, press interviews, rehearsal schedules. Each detail was a brick being laid, building a wall of terrifying reality around him. He found himself answering in monosyllables, his mind struggling to keep up. While he listened, his eyes were fixed on Chloe, who had stood up and was now gazing out at the ocean again, her back to him. She was so still, she could have been a statue carved from driftwood.

"So we'll have a car pick you up at 0800 on Monday week. Does that work for you, Leo?" Sarah chirped.

"Yes. Fine," he mumbled, his throat dry. The hum in his ears seemed to amplify, locking onto the frequency of the phone's electronic signal.

"Great! We are all just so thrilled for you, Leo. Your talent is so… unique. We think Australia is going to fall in love with it."

He hung up, the phone feeling slick with sweat in his palm. He walked back onto the verandah, the producer's plastic enthusiasm ringing in his ears. "They're sending a car," he said, needing to say it out loud to make it real. "Press interviews." Chloe didn't turn around. Her coffee cup was gone from the rail. He glanced around the small space—it wasn't on the floor, not on the table. It had simply vanished. He felt a dizzying lurch, as if the floor had tilted beneath his feet.

"Chlo? Where did your coffee go?"

She finally turned, her expression placid. "What coffee?" she asked, her brow furrowed in genuine confusion. "You were the one with the coffee, Leo."

He stared at her, then at his own empty cup on the table, then back at her face. The lie—or the lapse, or whatever it was—was so blatant, so calmly delivered, that he felt a crack form in the bright, incandescent surface of his day. He opened his mouth to argue, to point to the spot on the rail where the cup had been just moments before, but the words died in his throat. What was the point? Arguing would only upset her, drawing that sad, fragile veil back over her face. He was probably just scrambled from the news, the lack of sleep, the hard ride. His mind was playing tricks. It had to be.

"Right," he said, forcing a smile. "Yeah. My mistake."

She smiled back, that rare, brilliant smile returning. "Now," she said, her voice light and airy again. "Go and practice. Show me how transcendent you can be."

He retreated to the spare room, the command echoing in his head. The air in the small space was thick with the silent potential of the glasses. *Spiegel im Spiegel*. The idea was absurd, a technical nightmare. But as he looked at the glistening array on the table, a defiant spark flickered within him. *It's about making something beautiful out of nothing.* He sat down, the familiar scent of water and glass filling his senses. He wouldn’t attempt the whole piece, not yet. He would just try to find the opening notes, to see if it was even possible to sustain them, to create that hypnotic, bell-like repetition the piece demanded. He moistened his fingers and touched the rim of a glass. A perfect, clear A. He let it ring, feeling the vibration travel up his arm. Then he prepared to strike the next note, the high C-sharp. As his second finger approached the rim of the smaller glass, the hum in his head sharpened, rising in pitch until it perfectly matched the A that was already hanging in the air. The two tones locked together, the external sound from the glass and the internal one in his skull, creating a disorienting, pulsating beat in the centre of his brain. The sensation was so overwhelming he pulled his hands back as if the glass were red hot. The note died, and the hum receded to its usual background murmur. He sat there, breathing heavily, his heart hammering against his ribs. It wasn't just a hum. It was a note. And it was tuned to his music.

### Chapter 2

The world snapped back into focus with a painful clarity. Leo was on his stool, hands hovering over the glasses, his own ragged breathing the only sound in the small room. The hum in his skull had retreated to its familiar, unobtrusive corner on the edge of his hearing. He touched his temples, half-expecting to feel a vibration, but there was only cool, clammy skin. He tried to rationalise it. Auditory pareidolia, that's what it was. The brain's tendency to find patterns in random noise. He was stressed, sleep-deprived. With a series of loud, metallic clicks that seemed to echo in the stillness, he opened the case. The air was immediately filled with the rich, unmistakable scent of aged wood, horsehair, and rosin, a smell that bypassed his conscious thought and spoke directly to the oldest parts of his memory. There it lay, nestled in the worn, burgundy velvet lining. Its body, a deep, reddish-brown, seemed to glow with a life of its own. It was more beautiful than he remembered, a sleeping instrument, not a dead one.

He lifted it carefully, its familiar weight and shape settling against him as if no time had passed at all. He found the bow, the horsehair slack and yellowed, and tightened it with a few turns of the screw. It was a deep, resonant, complex voice, full of warmth and texture and woody vibration. It was the sound of a physical body, of gut and timber and friction. It was the sound of earth, not air; a voice, not a spirit. It filled the room not with a haunting, but with a presence.

His fingers, stiff and unpracticed on the fingerboard, felt clumsy. He didn't attempt the intricate Bach. He started with a simple C-major scale, the notes rough and not perfectly in tune, but solid and real. His muscle memory, buried for over a decade, slowly began to stir. He found a fragment of a simple folk song they had both learned as children, the melody emerging hesitantly at first, then with a growing confidence. The cello's voice was forgiving, its resonance covering his small mistakes, its warmth encouraging him. Anna had put her book down and was watching him, not with pity or concern, but with a quiet, luminous curiosity, as if she were meeting a part of him for the very first time.

He played for nearly an hour, the simple tunes of his childhood flowing one into another. The music was not a performance or a eulogy; it was a conversation with his own past, a re-acquaintance with a part of himself he had thought long lost. The act of making music with this instrument, the one that had been hers, was not painful. It was a connection, a continuation. He was not summoning her ghost; he was simply picking up a conversation that had been interrupted. He finished on a low, sustained C, letting the note resonate, feeling the deep vibration travel from the body of the cello through his own chest, a steadying, grounding hum. He lowered the bow, and the last of the note’s warmth faded into the sound of the rain outside. He looked at Anna, and in her soft smile, he saw not the end of a painful story, but the beautiful, unexpected beginning of a new harmony, a life filled with every kind of music.
